Class was a combination of lectures and discussion on readings.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: basics of immunology, physiology of immune system, history of disease
I learned a wide array of immunology concepts. I also learned how the information I was learning applied to SARS-CoV-2.
Developed a better understanding of how the immune system works and the biology of microbes. Also was able to practice reading scientific papers.

Immunology concepts were covered in depth and allowed me to understand scientific concepts when mentioned in news coverage and journal publications.

Historical events such as the 1918 flu pandemic, HIV/AIDS, and polio were integrated into the lessons which helped me to better understand the current COVID-19 pandemic.
A lot of specifics involving the human immune system as well as putting it into context of today's pandemic.
This class helped me understand today's pandemic.
I learned how to evaluate and discuss scientific readings, and I learned many new aspects about how the immune system functions.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: instructor was extremely knowledgeable and flexible with content matter; very interesting material
weaknesses: problem set grading seemed arbitrary at times, unclear expectations

Strengths: there was a PDF of content that paired well with the PowerPoints from class; the alternating schedule of quizzes and tests ensured I was retaining what I was learning in class; Weaknesses: the content could get a little too in-depth at points that it was very difficult to understand

Stength of the class was that it was VERY engaging. The lectures during the beginning of class were presented in a very interesting way and followed up questions that expanded understanding and connected the material. The second half of class would include a discussion on a reading that would also provide a different perspective and allow for more student interaction on the topic. Another strength was that even though the class had a large focus on biology, it also involved other aspects such as art on the subject or real world events. Shorter and more frequent assignment forced constant review of the material and a better retention of the material. Additionally, combination of assignments made the class more interesting. Having a final paper and project at the end of the class rather than a large final was also a strength as it allowed students to take a deeper dive into topics that they were more interested in. Fantastic class and I don't see what else could be done to improve it.

Strengths: small class size allowed for lively discussions and personal engagement with the professor. A variety of instructional and assessment methods were used which ensured I was almost always interested in what we were doing in class. The lecture packet put together by the professor was a great help and very appreciated.

Weaknesses: not any major ones I can think of.
Since it is a first-year seminar I thought the class was pretty engaging and overall enjoyable. The readings were very interesting.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: good
The Zoom format facilitated lectures and discussions.

Small in person meetings were promoted and were a great way to have some interaction while still staying safe. Breakout rooms and group projects were utilized in order to create closer bonds between students. The only thing that could have been imporved is to use a specific program other than Canvas that could make readings more engaging and promote particiaption.

The virtual seminar format was pretty smooth. Breakout rooms allowed us to have small group discussions and get to know classmates better. 

An improvement could be offering virtual office hours. I think many students would have enjoyed the opportunity to talk with the professor more and have conversations with her in a small group.

Since it it a first-year seminar, people were pretty engaged and willing to participate. Everyone's cameras were on for the most part and for the most part it wasn't awkward to conduct the seminar over zoom.
very well engaged and caring teacher

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes, anyone interested in immunology or disease
I would recommend this course to anybody who is interested in how the immune system functions. It was an extremely engaging course because the applications were very apparent.
I would definately recommend this class to another student. Would recommend it more for students that have interest in biology or medicine.

Yes, and a mid-level to strong background in biology helps a lot. If you have less background, be prepared to put in more work, but the professor's lecture notes packet is immensely helpful in understanding some of the more complicated immunology topics. Students will come away with a scientific and historical understanding of immunology and infectious diseases that will serve them well in the future regardless of their main area of focus.
I would if the student was looking to really dig deep into the mechanics of the immune system. Unless you think this is interesting, I would not recommend it.
Yes, this course is very interesting and is applicable to life in the pandemic today.
Yes, Professor Kavathas is very knowledgeable in her field of immunology, and she cares for each of her students. I loved learning in her class and she always made the class fun.

Yes! Prof Kavathas is the best. The course can be hard and covers materials that are quite detailed and advanced, but Prof K's teaching enthusiasm and the structure of the course make it enjoyable.
It is easy to get behind on the lecture materials, so regular reviews are necessary to stay on top of the increasingly nuanced immunological concepts.
